comment.author: 21061284@N05
comment._content: Search William Hope. He was one of the premiere spirit photographers of the early Twentieth Century and was considered by believers and supporters to be a true master of the art of producing spirits on ordinary photographic plates. To others, he was a clever trickster and while he had more than his share of detractors, he was often accused of fraud but was never caught at it -- thanks to the controversy that surrounded the main attempt to expose him.

comment.author: 10697960@N07
comment._content: You'd have to be retarded to believe these pictures are real. If these are in fact from the 1920's, then this guy figured out a way to fake them and make money off of them. They're still retarded.

comment.author: 43384739@N06
comment._content:
These arn't real.In the 20's the cameras used to sometimes get the previous images burned into the lenses.This caused the "ghostly effect (Seen in this photo).So people used to get hyped  about it all and think it was ghosts when it was  previous shots burned onto the lens.

Chris

comment.author: 51716700@N00
comment._content: Yes folks, they are fake, we all know, no point in letting us know, but keep one thing in mind. These photos were done in the early days of photo manipulation. While they look incredibly fake to our Photoshop  and digitial animation jaded eyes, this was cutting edge technology of it's day. Techniques like using "shrouds" to hide cut lines, even doing the double exposures themselves were genius for their time!

comment.author: 12306929@N04
comment._content:
These to me are obvious fakes but they demonstrate an artful technique 
in that they do give pause !  The art is the image transfering.  These bring to light numerous examples seen through the years of multiple exposure techniques some better than these----but these are artful also in the sense that they are identifiable as concocted phenomena and at the same time suggest some "ethereal" happenings at the time of the photo-snap !

comment.author: 91552329@N00
comment._content:
Ah I remember those heady times of multiple exposure, in the good old days. 
As a kid, I could NEVER remember to wind the film on.  I could never decide whether it was better to wind the film on straight after the last photo, or before the next frame.  I never quite developed a good habit. 
And of course if you wound it on, you risked an accidental exposure inside the camera case (my cameras were dead posh) 

Yes of course its fake - or did they have the same problem as me?

comment.author: 42656586@N06
comment._content: This is about the 7th or 8th spirit pic I've view from "Hope" & at first I was amazed, but now I can clearly tell they're faked. the biggest givaway is the long veils each spirit is wearing - if it had only been one or 2 photos where a spirit was wearing a veil, that would be one thing, buy almost ALL spirits are wearing these. Secondly, the free space at the top of the photos - if he was a professional photographer...why would he leave all that free space at the top??? Funny because I'm actually a huge believer in phenomenon & am very openminded, but I also have common sense and these phots are clearly faked :( too bad....but faked or not - they're still cool :)
